data.description: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit the park.
entranceFees.title: Park Fees

data.directionsInfo: Arkansas Post National Memorial is located in southeastern Arkansas. The entrance to the park is on Arkansas Hwy 169, seven miles south of Gillett, via US Hwy 165 (The Great River Road), and about 20 miles northeast of Dumas, via US 165.

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open daily: 7:00 a.m. to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Grounds Hours

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: confluence of two rivers
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: the Alligator Slough footbridge
images.caption: The Alligator Slough footbridge

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: Arkansas Post National Memorial is in the Lower Mississippi Riverine Forest ecoregion.
images.caption: Located at the confluence of two rivers, Arkansas Post has served as a gathering place for many cultures throughout human history - it represents cultural cooperation, conflict, synthesis, and diversity.

images.title: Arkansas Post National Monument
images.altText: Over the three centuries of history at Arkansas Post, the area has been greatly changed by both natu
images.caption: Located at the northern edge of the Gulf coastal plain, the Arkansas Post's native growth ranges from prairie grasses and lowland hardwood forests to wetland marshes near the bayous and river.

images.title: Living History
images.altText: Arkansas Post National Monument cannon firing
images.caption: During the Civil War, Confederate troops tried to maintain tactical control of the confluence of the Arkansas and White Rivers, and in 1862 they constructed a massive earthen fortification known as Fort Hindman at the Post. In January 1863 Union troops d

data.weatherInfo: Arkansas shares the same climate classification as the rest of the southeastern United States: humid subtropical. This type of climate features relatively mild winters and hot, steamy summers.
data.name: Arkansas Post

data.description: Established in 1972, Buffalo National River flows freely for 135 miles and is one of the few remaining undammed rivers in the lower 48 states. Once you arrive, prepare to journey from running rapids to quiet pools while surrounded by massive bluffs as you cruise through the Ozark Mountains down to the White River.
data.directionsInfo: Buffalo National River is a long, narrow park that is crossed by three main highways. Highways 7, 43, and 62/65 are the main roads out of Harrison, Arkansas that will take you to the Buffalo River, depending on which part of the park you wish to visit. GPS systems are not reliable in this area so please call ahead for directions or pick up a map of the area beforehand.

operatingHours.description: Buffalo National River is 135 miles long. The park is open 24 hours.
operatingHours.name: Buffalo National River

images.title: Indian Rockhouse
images.altText: A large bluff shelter near Buffalo Point.
images.caption: Every year thousands of people hike to the Indian Rockhouse to admire this large bluff shelter.

images.title: Skull Rock
images.altText: Kayakers floating towards Skull Rock near Buffalo Point.
images.caption: A peaceful day on the Buffalo River as kayakers approach Skull Rock and Buffalo Point.

images.title: Steel Creek Campground
images.altText: Camping at Steel Creek
images.caption: Camping along the Buffalo River is a wonderful way to enjoy the park.

images.title: Floating the Buffalo
images.altText: Floaters on the river.
images.caption: Canoeing and kayaking the river is a wonderful way to spend a day at the Buffalo.

images.title: Sod Collier Homestead
images.altText: Historic homestead built by the Collier Family.
images.caption: Many historic structures are scattered along the Buffalo River reminding us of the hardworking settlers that once called this river valley home.

images.title: Smallmouth Bass Fishing
images.altText: Fisherman with smallmouth bass.
images.caption: Fishing for smallmouth bass is a popular activity on the Buffalo River.

data.weatherInfo: Summer in the Ozarks can be very hot and humid. Please check the weather forecast prior to your arrival and plan accordingly. The weather the rest of the year has the potential to be wet and cool or dry and warm. Please pay special attention to river levels and the rain forecast when planning a trip on the river. River levels can rise dramatically in a short period of time so please be aware of conditions.
data.name: Buffalo

data.description: Explore life on the edge of frontier and Indian Territory through the stories of soldiers, the Trail of Tears, scandals, outlaws, and lawmen who pursued them. From the establishment of the first Fort Smith on December 25, 1817, to the final days of Judge Isaac C. Parker's jurisdiction over Indian Territory in 1896, Fort Smith National Historic Site preserves almost 80 years of history.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee is for individual admittance into the exhibits inside the visitor center building. Your receipt will be good for seven days from the time of purchase. There is no fee for viewing the grounds.
entranceFees.title: Entrance walk in - per person

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass allows the pass holder and 3 adults (16 and older) free entrance to all the exhibits in the visitor center. The pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase, expiring the last day of that month.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Smith National Historic Site Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: From Interstate 40 Eastbound: Exit at Roland, and drive six miles on highway 64 to downtown Fort Smith. From Interstate 40 Westbound & from North I 540 & Fayetteville, take Interstate 40 westbound to I 540 south. Exit west on Rogers Ave. and continue to downtown. In the downtown area: On Rogers or Garrison Ave turn south at 4th St. Turn right onto Garland Ave. At the end of the next block is the entrance to the main parking lot. Parking is also available on Third Street.

operatingHours.description: Park grounds are open from 30 min before sunrise and 30 minutes after sunset.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds and Trails

operatingHours.description: The Commissary is considered the oldest building in Fort Smith. The Gallows is a replica built on the site of the original gallows.
operatingHours.name: Gallows and Commissary

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Aerial view of visitor center
images.caption: The former barracks, courthouse, and jail serves as the park's visitor center

images.title: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.altText: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.caption: In 1845, Fort Smith was converted to a supply depot. With this mission, Fort Smith became one of the busiest supply posts in the southwest.

images.title: Entrance sign
images.altText: Entrance sign in snow
images.caption: Entrance sign along the river trail on a snowy day.

images.title: Foundations of First Fort Smith
images.altText: Foundations of first Fort Smith and Arkansas River
images.caption: Foundations of the first Fort Smith with Arkansas River in the background

images.title: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.altText: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.caption: A jail wagon like this one was use the transport prisoners to the Federal Courthouse 6th Street.

images.title: Supply Wagon and Visitor Center
images.altText: Supply Wagon and visitor center
images.caption: Supply Wagon and visitor center

data.weatherInfo: Fort Smith weather includes four distinct, yet temperate seasons. Spring and fall are usually mild while late summer is hot and humid. During winter months, temperatures occasionally dip into the teens. Forecast often changes dramatically due to surrounding weather influences. Arkansas's central location allows weather systems from all directions to influence its climate. The area is prone to flash flooding and river flooding in rainy seasons.
data.name: Fort Smith

data.description: Hot Springs National Park has a rich cultural past. The grand architecture of our historic bathhouses is equally matched by the natural curiosities that have been drawing people here for hundreds of years. Ancient thermal springs, mountain views, incredible geology, forested hikes, and abundant creeks – all in the middle of town – make Hot Springs National Park a unique and beautiful destination.
data.directionsInfo: From Little Rock: Take I-30W towards Texarkana. Exit 111 for US 70W/Hot Springs. Turn Right onto Spring St. Turn Right onto Central Ave. Drive North, the Park will be on the right after Reserve St. From Texarkana: Take 1-30E. Exit 78 for AR-7 and turn left under the highway. Follow AR-7 North for 31 miles. AR-7 becomes Central Ave., the Park will be on the right after Reserve Street.

operatingHours.description:
Arlington Lawn, Grand Promenade, sidewalks on Bathhouse Row, Reserve Street, and Fountain Street, except for walk through traffic, are open from to 5:00 am to 10:00 pm, daily. 

Roads to Hot Springs Mountain, North Mountain and West Mountain Summit are open to vehicle traffic from 8:00 am to 10:00 pm.
operatingHours.name: Public Areas and Park Roads

data.weatherInfo: Average temperatures in Hot Springs can range from about 90°F (32°C) to less than 27°F (-2.7°C). Summer days can be hot and humid, with heat index values up to 110ºF (43ºC). Winter wind chills can make temperatures feel much colder, as low as 15ºF (-9.4ºC). Spring and fall typically have the most rainfall. Generally, Hot Springs experiences mild weather throughout the year.
data.name: Hot Springs

data.fullName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
data.description: In 1957, Little Rock Central High School was the epicenter of confrontation and a catalyst for change as the fundamental test for the United States to enforce African American civil rights following Brown v. Board of Education. Learn how the sacrifice and struggle endured by the Little Rock Nine have provided opportunities and opened doors for those seeking equality and education around the world.

emailAddresses.description: Email the park at this address for questions, directions, programming, or other general information. To reserve a guided tour, please call the park during business hours (9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. CST/CDT, daily).

entranceFees.description: Admission to Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site Visitor Center is free.  Guided tours are admission free, but must be reserved in advance to guarantee availability.
entranceFees.title: Admission and Program Fees

data.directionsInfo: From I-630, take Exit 2B (Dr. Martin Luther King Drive). Go south (away from the Arkansas State Capitol) to W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Turn right (head west) and continue 0.5 miles. The Visitor Center is on the right at the corner of W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive and Park Street. Parking lot entrance is located just before the intersection with Park Street, directly across from the historic Magnolia/Mobil Gas Station and diagonally across from Central High School (still a functioning high school).

operatingHours.description:
The Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site Visitor Center is currently open Tuesday through Saturday (10:00 a.m. CST/CDT to 4:00 p.m. CST/CDT).

The Magnolia Mobil Gas Station & Little Rock Central High School are closed to the public and not available for public use. The commemorative garden is open daily for public visitation and use from 7:00 a.m. CST/CDT until sunset.

Guests may visit the NHS daily; we recommend the NPS App for digital content on days when the visitor center is closed.
operatingHours.name: Little Rock Central High School NHS

addresses.line1: Little Rock Central High School NHS
addresses.line2: 2120 W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive

addresses.line1: Little Rock Central High School NHS

images.caption: Images of the Little Rock Nine’s persistence and Elizabeth’s brave walk through the mob to the sanctuary of the bench captured their enduring legacy of “moral courage” that has inspired others around

images.credit: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
images.title: The Little Rock Nine
images.altText: The Little Rock Nine exit the doors at Central High under troop escort
images.caption: In September 1957, Little Rock Central High School became a symbol for change and a catalyst for transformation in the civil rights movement as the first fundamental test to the United States’ resolve to enforce African-American civil rights in the face

images.altText: The Magnolia Mobil Gas Station, a white stucco facility with terracotta roof
images.caption: The Magnolia Mobil Gas Station, the de facto media headquarters during the 1957 desegregation crisis.

data.weatherInfo: Arkansas weather can change quickly. While the state is in a moderate temperate zone, it does experience strong thunderstorms, tornadoes and flash floods. In winter, "snow" events tend to quickly turn to thin ice which can be difficult to see and to clear. Summer temperatures and humidity can lead to dehydration, heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Visitors are advised to dress in layers and be prepared for precipitation.
data.name: Little Rock Central High School

data.description: On March 7-8, 1862, over 23,000 soldiers fought here to decide the fate of Missouri which was a turning point of the war in the Trans-Mississippi. This 4,300-acre battlefield honors those who fought and died on these hallowed grounds. Pea Ridge was the most pivotal Civil War battle west of the Mississippi River.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter at Pea Ridge National Military Park and passes are not available for purchase.
entranceFees.title: Fees and Passes

data.directionsInfo: The entrance road is located on Highway 62, 1.3 miles east of the intersection of Highways 62 and 72. As one is driving along highway 62, watch for the brown road signs directing one to the entrance road to the park's visitor center.

operatingHours.description: Pea Ridge National Military Park The battlefield driving tour road is open for visitors to tour 7 days a week from 6 am to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Elkhorn Tavern
images.altText: A reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern.
images.caption: Used as a field hospital during the Battle of Pea Ridge, the Elkhorn Tavern is a focal point at Pea Ridge National Military Park.

images.title: Park Tour Road in Fall
images.altText: Photo of road with trees on both sides of road. Trees have Fall Foliage
images.caption: Park tour road in the fall.

images.caption: Photo taken at sunset showing the deep green trees.

images.title: Silent Field
images.altText: Photo of sun setting over the golden grass the battlefield.
images.caption: Silent Field is a photo that shows the sun setting over the golden grass of the battlefield. Men fought and died in this field, on a cold day in March of 1862.

images.title: Rededication to the Elkhorn Tavern
images.altText: Photo of Union Union artilleryman reenactors standing in front of building.
images.caption: Photo of Union Union artilleryman reenactors standing in front of the Elkhorn Tavern for the rededication of the building.

images.altText: Photo of Union Infantrymen reenactors standing in front of building with large crowd.
images.caption: Photo of Union Infantrymen reenactors standing in front of the Elkhorn Tavern, with large crowd during demonstration on the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Pea Ridge. .

data.weatherInfo: Pea Ridge National Military Park is located in the northwestern part of the state and is on a part of the Ozark Plateau. The climate is hot and humid in the summers, has mild temperatures in the fall, and drier and cooler temperatures in the winter. During the spring and summer active thunderstorms can pop up. During the winter months, the wind chill factor can make the temperature feel much colder than the air temperature. The winters can be cold with some snow and ice.
data.name: Pea Ridge

data.fullName: President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home National Historic Site
data.description: Named for the father who died shortly before his birth, William Jefferson Blythe III later became the 42nd President of the United States. In this place, the experiences shared with his mother & grandparents in rural Arkansas developed the broad views on race relations, social justice, and public service that defined his presidency and life after the White House. For Bill Clinton, "Hope was home."

emailAddresses.description:
The Visitor Center includes temporary exhibit displays, a Jefferson National Parks Association bookstore/gift shop, and National Park Service staff to receive visitors and answer questions.

Note: an internet search for the NHS tend to direct you to the "Boyhood Home" on 13th Street instead of the "Birthplace Home." Use the NHS address at 117 S. Hervey Street on a GPS, etc. to reach the National Park Service site.

entranceFees.description: There is no entry fee for the Visitor Center or Birthplace Home tour. However, we do sell the Annual and Senior passes and issue the Access passes.
entranceFees.title: Free

data.directionsInfo: President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home NHS is located in Hope, Arkansas - approx. 30 miles from Texarkana (Texas/Arkansas), 114 miles from Little Rock, Arkansas & 209 miles from Dallas, Texas. From I-30, use Exit 30 and travel south on Hwy 278 (Hervey Street) for approximately 2 miles. The Birthplace Home is on your left at the corner of 2nd Street and S Hervey Street; the Visitor Center is located on Division Street (immediately northeast of the Birthplace Home).

operatingHours.description:
The President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home NHS Visitor Center is closed on Wednesdays, Thursdays, New Year's Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. 

The NHS grounds and the Virginia Clinton Kelley Memorial Garden are open daily for public visitation and use from sunrise until sunset.
operatingHours.name: President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home National Historic Site

images.title: Birthplace Home
images.altText: The birthplace home of President Bill Clinton illuminated at dusk.
images.caption: President Clinton spent the first four years of his life in this home being raised by his maternal grandparents.

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Exterior of Visitor Center building with landscape surrounding
images.caption: Exterior of Visitor Center from Hervey Street

images.altText: A view of the living room with a fireplace, rug, recliner and other furniture
images.caption: The living room inside the Clinton Birthplace Home

images.title: The formal living room of the Clinton Birthplace Home
images.altText: A view of the formal living room features a tricycle, table and chairs, and radio
images.caption: The formal living room of the Clinton Birthplace Home

images.title: Memorial Garden
images.altText: Memorial garden for his mother, Virginia
images.caption: Memorial garden for his mother, Virginia

data.weatherInfo: Average temperatures in Hope can range from 30ºF to 60ºF in winter, 40ºF to 80ºF in the spring, 65ºF to 95ºF in summer, and 50ºF to 75ºF in the fall. Humidity in late spring, summer and early fall can make temperatures feel hotter and lead to dehydration or heatstroke. We recommend that visitors in these seasons dress comfortably and drink plenty of water to beat the heat. Inclement weather (tornadoes, thunderstorms) are possible at times, so check local weather conditions before your visit to Arkansas.
data.name: President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.

entranceFees.description: There are NO USER OR ENTRY FEES fees for the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail. NOMINAL FEES may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please visit Plan Your Visit / Places To Go for an interactive map and extensive list of places to visit by state. Contact information is available for each site to call and find out about fees.
entranceFees.title: General Entrance Fee Information

data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears
